sub_nodes.description: When a privileged bias is challenged by pressure from particular data, that data source should be flagged as suspect and trusted less, at least until such time that there is more information about the case (Neff and Nagy 2016, Tanner and Medin 2004, Baskaran et al. 2016, Tabibian et al. 2016).

sub_nodes.title: Statistical-Behavioral Trust Establishment
sub_nodes.mini_description: Intelligently managing trust of other agents based on their behavior
sub_nodes.description: In order to determine which sources of information, or which agents, in an environment can be trusted, techniques that analyze those entities' behaviors statistically may be employed (Russell et al. 2015). Intelligently managing trust in this manner can be applied to other AI systems (Probst and Kasera 2007), and generally, reputation models (Sabater and Sierra 2005) allow such mechanisms to scale (Neff and Nagy 2016).

sub_nodes.title: Misuse Risk
sub_nodes.mini_description: How to deal with the risk of operators misusing an advanced agent
sub_nodes.description: Another type of security risk is that a highly capable agent can be misused by its operators (Yampolskiy 2016b). There may well be technical strategies, e.g. requiring a large number of operators or sources of values, to help mitigate this risk, but this is very underexplored.

links.reason: From Misuse Risk also see Modeling Operator Intent which addresses detection of discord within controlling operators with respect to each other and with respect to previously loaded values.

sub_nodes.title: Norm Denial of Service
sub_nodes.mini_description: An agent launching a DOS attack against environmentally-enforced safety mechanisms, including soft constraints from social norms
sub_nodes.description: Soft constraints such as norms may have associated recovery mechanisms that can be susceptible to timing, concurrency, and volume-based exploitation. Denial of service attacks on environmentally-enforced recovery or safety mechanisms may therefore occur when an agent launches a sustained volley of violations against such environmental soft constraints (Carmo and Jones 1996, Loukas 2006). If recovery mechanisms lack a meta level flow control to guard against such situations and are unable to meet the concurrency demanded, such an attack might cause recovery procedures associated with subsequent violations to be incompletely processed or uninitiated (Governatori and Rotolo 2003, Loukas 2006).

links.reason: From Norm Denial of Service also see Grounded Ethical Evolution which may be susceptible to this.
From Norm Denial of Service also see Metareasoning which might seem called for in constraint enforcement mechanisms.
From Norm Denial of Service also see Logical Induction which can in theory be used in service of meta level flow in such situations.
From Norm Denial of Service also see Handling Improper External Behavior as this can also be regarding third-party entities.

sub_nodes.title: Privileged Biases
sub_nodes.mini_description: Pretrained or specified biases can be weighed higher than others, allowed narrower tolerances, allowed to change more slowly, or have triggers informing of attacks or adversarial pressures on it
sub_nodes.description: Specific biases, relationship valences, or soft or hard constraints within an agent's world model can be annotated as privileged and weighted highly in tradeoff calculations (Tanner and Medin 2004). These may model values. Such biases can be allowed narrower tolerances, allowed to change more slowly, or have associated triggers informing the agent of adversarial pressures or attacks on them (Tabibian et al. 2016, Baskaran et al. 2016, Li et al. 2015).

sub_nodes.title: Red Team Analysis
sub_nodes.mini_description: Using an adversarial entity or team to probe and identify vulnerabilities in the system of interest, usually in a blackbox context
sub_nodes.description: Red team analysis uses an adversarial entity or team to probe and identify vulnerabilities in the system of interest, usually in a blackbox context. The recent DARPA Cyber Grand Challenge likewise had various automated adversarial teams whitebox scan their own systems and blackbox scan their opponents, patch themselves, develop exploits, and penetrate opponent systems, all in a matter of minutes rather than the weeks to months that humans would normally take for the same steps (Song and Alves-Foss 2015, Musca 2016).

links.reason: From Red Team Analysis also see Automated Vulnerability Finding which addresses finding vulnerabilities in whiteboxes rather than blackboxes.

sub_nodes.title: Penetration Testing
sub_nodes.mini_description: Using an adversarial entity to attempt to break into the system of interest in various ways
sub_nodes.description: Penetration testing specifically uses an adversarial entity to attempt to break into the system of interest in various ways and to go as deeply into its systems as possible. Agents can analyze the vulnerabilities of other systems and agents in this way (Brun and Ernst 2004), and can correlate this analysis with analyses of the likely source code generating those vulnerabilities.

sub_nodes.title: Standard IT Security
sub_nodes.mini_description: Analyzing particularly vulnerable or sensitive targets of attack within an AI system and defending them
sub_nodes.description: Cybersecurity is applicable and important to any kind of software, and artificial intelligence is no exception (Russell et al. 2015). AI failures can come about through lapses in security (Yampolskiy 2016a, Barreno et al. 2010). Unique to AI are the specific vulnerable or sensitive targets of attack within an AI system, and the active ways of defending those (Yampolskiy 2014, Papernot et al. 2016).

sub_nodes.title: AI to Support Security
sub_nodes.mini_description: Utilizing advanced automated intelligence capabilities to protect the AI system against exploits and intrusion
sub_nodes.description: For advanced and general purpose agents, it should be quite possible to utilize its own advanced automation and intelligence analysis capabilities to, analyze potential malware (Rieck et al. 2011), protect itself against active exploits, detect intrusions (Lane 2000), and automatically check for potential exploits it may be vulnerable to. As AI matures, AIs one wishes to keep good will also need to protect themselves against not just human hackers, but also AIs that have either become, or were designed to be, bad (Pistono and Yampolskiy 2016). Likewise, both context-aware and narrow AIs will need to protect the security and privacy of others they are serving, so an understanding and application of differential privacy (Zhang et al. 2016a, Tossou and Dimitrakakis 2016) practices would be called for (Russell et al. 2015).

sub_nodes.title: Security-Validated Software Engineering
sub_nodes.mini_description: Including side-channel vulnerability assessment in the validation process
sub_nodes.description: When creating advanced, powerful, or high-stakes AI systems, security-validated software engineering practices are called for. Given that vulnerabilities can use a growing array of unexpected side-channels (Guri et al. 2016), and given that advanced agents can be more creative about side-channel use than people are, a side-channel vulnerability assessment would be important to such validation, yet it wouldn't be able to provide any guarantees.

sub_nodes.title: Utility Function Security
sub_nodes.mini_description: Establishing extra privileges and protections around modifications of an explicit or implicit utility function
sub_nodes.description: It would make sense to establish extra privileges and protections around modifications of an explicit or implicit utility function of an AI, given that it's a highly centralized and leveraged point (Yampolskiy 2014).

sub_nodes.title: Verified Downstack Software
sub_nodes.mini_description: Utilizing a stack of verified software as high as is practical
sub_nodes.description: Because software verification and correct-by-construction are such powerful techniques to reduce the kinds of implementation issues that are often exploited during security events, utilizing a stack of as much verified software, as high as is practical in the stack, would be prudent. Even just very well-tested underlying platform can provide similar benefits, e.g. the DARPA SAFE program aims to build an integrated hardware-software system with a flexible metadata rule engine (DeHon et al. 2011), on which can be built memory safety, fault isolation, and other protocols that could improve security by preventing exploitable flaws (Russell et al. 2015).

sub_nodes.title: Tripwires
sub_nodes.mini_description: Introduce plausible vulnerabilities, with corresponding hidden triggers and reporting, that an agent would exploit if the reward function is being gamed
sub_nodes.description: To catch internal misbehavior, one can introduce plausible vulnerabilities, with alert triggers, that an agent can exploit and will only do so if its reward function is being gamed (Babcock et al. 2016, Amodei et al. 2016). This technique is also useful for catching intrusions by external threats as it is classically applied.

sub_nodes.title: Validation
sub_nodes.mini_description: Ensuring that the right system specification is provided for the core of the agent given stakeholders' goals for the system
sub_nodes.description:
Given even verified software, environmental assumptions can easily not hold in the real world, or the requirements that led to the specification may be faulty or lacking. These sort of specification errors are quite usual in the world of software verification, where it is often observed that writing correct specifications can be more difficult than writing correct code (Russell et al. 2015). Validation is the process of ensuring that a system that meets its formal requirements does not have undesirable behaviors or consequences. It is asking the question "Did I build (or ask for) the right system?".

Ensuring that the formal requirements, the specification, considers all relevant dynamics, and will be beneficial and desirable, does not actually fit into current formally provable paradigms. In order to build systems that robustly behave well, one currently needs to decide what good behavior means in each application domain. This ethical question of good is tied closely to questions of what technologies and engineering techniques are available, how reliable they are, and what trade-offs can be made all areas where computer science, software engineering, machine learning, and broader AI expertise are valuable. In practical application, a significant consideration is the computational expense of different behavioral standards or ethical theories, i.e. that if a standard cannot be evaluated sufficiently expeditiously to guide behavior in safety-critical situations, cheaper approximations should be used (Wallach and Allen 2008). It is therefore likely best for different complexities of ethical or moral reasoning to be used for different timescales.

Designing simplified rules, such as those meant to govern a self-driving cars strategic decisions in critical situations, will likely require expertise from both ethicists and computer scientists (Russell et al. 2015). This is relatively straightforward when specific safety limitations, behaviors, and ethical constraints are known upfront for AI systems that are largely specified upfront (Berkenkamp et al. 2016, Ullman et al. 2009), but more powerful and operationally-flexible systems require much more sophistication. Computational models of ethical reasoning may shed light on questions of computational expense and the viability of reliable ethical reasoning methods (Asaro 2006, Sullins 2011). Being able to assure known bounded behaviors from methods and systems that learn will also be important for both medium-term and long-term safety. Validation encompasses ensuring an agent understands its environment, decisions, and actions, and that it acts robustly-in-accordance with its operators' wishes.

In the long term, AI systems might become much more powerful, general-purpose, and autonomous, a regime where failures of validity would carry significantly higher costs than with today's systems. To maximize the long-term value of validity research, machine learning researchers might focus on anticipating, preventing, detecting, and mitigating the types of otherwise unexpected generalization that would be most problematic for very general and capable AI systems. If some concepts could be learned reliably, it might become possible to use those to define tasks or constraints that minimize the chances of unintended consequences even when agents become very general and capable. This topic has been underexplored, so both theoretical and experimental research on it may be useful (Russell et al. 2015).

sub_nodes.title: Averting Instrumental Incentives
sub_nodes.mini_description: Designing systems so they assuredly do not have instrumental incentives, e.g. to manipulate and deceive the operators, compete for scarce resources, or prevent their maintenance
sub_nodes.description: It has been argued that intelligent systems that aim toward some objective have emergent instrumental incentives, pressures to create subplans, to give them more time, power, and resources to fulfill their objectives (Omohundro 2008). These instrumental pressures, and the flexibility to act on those pressures, are relatively uncommon in today's rather narrow systems, but would seem much more expected and pronounced as AIs become more general (Bostrom 2014), and understand a wider array of contexts, modalities, and fields. Progress on formalizing this class of problems has only been recent (Benson-Tilsen and Soares 2016). How can one design and train systems such that they robustly lack default incentives to manipulate and deceive the operators, compete for scarce resources, prevent their maintenance (Omohundro 2008), and generally avert negative instrumental behaviors? (Taylor et al. 2016, Bostrom 2014) Averting these implicit pressures in a design is much more difficult than it may appear initially, and there are numerous subtleties to consider (Armstrong 2010, Armstrong 2013, Benson-Tilsen and Soares 2016). Sophisticated techniques to avoid such incentives can be needed not only for agents but also oracle-style question answering AIs (Armstrong 2016).

links.reason: From Averting Instrumental Incentives also see Operator Value Learning where systems can avert instrumental incentives by maintaining uncertainty over the truly desired goal.

From Averting Instrumental Incentives also see Switchable Objective Functions whereby faulty interpretations of primary objective can be safely corrected without the default instrumental pressure to prevent such a change.

sub_nodes.title: Averting Paranoia
sub_nodes.mini_description: Making intelligent systems such that they do not spend an inordinate amount of resources determining the trustworthiness or ulterior motives of their operators
sub_nodes.description: Another instrumental pressure is to constantly scan or prepare for possible ill-intent or possible information leakage. While security precautions and vigilence are important, an arbitrarily high amount of resources can be spent on threat detection and avoidance, while that should typically be tempered to be sufficient to prevent and deal with realistic threats (Colby 2013).

links.reason: From Averting Paranoia also see Computational Deference on techniques for having an agent trust its operators.
From Averting Paranoia also see Mild Optimization for more on optimizing objectives and subobjectives to an appropriate amount but no more.
From Averting Paranoia also see Handling Improper External Behavior against which this needs to be balanced.

sub_nodes.title: Domesticity
sub_nodes.mini_description: Safely incentivizing an intelligent agent to be low-impact to the world
sub_nodes.description: The optimizers of today do not annex or use excessive resources not because doing so wouldn't lead to more optimal solutions to the function they're optimizing, but because they lack the capability to annex resources. This will change as AI becomes more general in its capabilities. It has been argued that explicitly and safely incentivizing such an intelligent agent to be low-impact on its environment will therefore be necessary (Armstrong et al. 2012, Soares and Fallenstein 2014a).

sub_nodes.title: Computational Humility
sub_nodes.mini_description: Algorithmic techniques enabling an agent to behave more humbly and moderate the modeled weights on its own utility
sub_nodes.description: Algorithmic techniques enabling an agent to humble itself (Srivastava et al. 2914) and moderate its views of its own importance can be termed computational humility.

links.reason: From Computational Humility also see Perceptual Distance Agnostic World Models which can aid humble knowledge representation.

sub_nodes.title: Generalized Fallibility Awareness
sub_nodes.mini_description: Having an agent know that none of its hypotheses might model the world well enough, biasing to consider its operators are less flawed than it is
sub_nodes.description: One central type of deference for advanced agents is to know that it may be that none of its hypotheses model the world well enough, and additionally biasing to consider its operators are less flawed than it is (Taylor et al. 2016), so letting them shut it down or modify it if it seems like that's what they want to do. An agent can try to model all of the ways it's flawed, but that may require that those models not be discounted by their own mechanism (Taylor et al. 2016), an open issue.

links.reason: From Generalized Fallibility Awareness also see Computational Deference which includes the very related control-centered aspects of corrigibility.

sub_nodes.title: Resource Value Uncertainty
sub_nodes.mini_description: Maintaining a model of uncertainty about the importance of underexplored entities, relationships, and dynamics
sub_nodes.description: Maintaining dynamic bayesian uncertainty regarding the importance or value of unexplored and underexplored or uncharacterized entities, relationships, and dynamics can significantly effect humble treatment of others (Srivastava et al. 2914, Mallah 2014). Reasonable multilevel aggregation would be needed to deal with constructs of varying temporal, physical, and complexity scales (Snijders and Bosker 2011, Mallah 2017).

sub_nodes.title: Temporal Discount Rates
sub_nodes.mini_description: Using the effects of large temporal discount rates on resource acquisition strategies to temper acquisitiveness
sub_nodes.description: Resource acquisition strategies can be tempered by the effects of applying a large temporal discount rate on the expected reward (Russell et al. 2015).

sub_nodes.title: Impact Measures
sub_nodes.mini_description: Methods to quantify the amount an agent does or can do to change the world
sub_nodes.description: Methods to quantify the amount an agent does, or can do, to change the world become necessary in such regimes. Using such measures, and other techniques, one can start exploring what sorts of mechanisms, including regularizers, might incentivize a system to pursue its goals with minimal side effects (Amodei et al. 2016, Taylor et al. 2016).

sub_nodes.title: Avoiding Negative Side Effects
sub_nodes.mini_description: Ways to ensure an agent won't disturb the environment in negative ways while pursuing its goals, ideally without specifying in advance what not to disturb
sub_nodes.description: If possible, one should aim to ensure that the agent won't disturb the environment in specifically negative ways while pursuing its goals, as opposed to in any way at all, and we'd ideally like to do so without specifying what not to disturb (Amodei et al. 2016).

sub_nodes.title: Multi-agent Approaches
sub_nodes.mini_description: Transparency of, and cooperation toward, a shared reward function by multiple agents
sub_nodes.description: Cooperative multiagent techniques may also disinventivize negative side effects. Transparency of, and cooperation toward, a shared reward function by multiple agents will continually solicit input from multiple stakeholders, and in so doing reduce risk of undesired outcomes per their varied models (Amodei et al. 2016). For example, biasing toward goal transparency (Greene et al. 2016) via autoencoding reward functions, or alternatively cooperative inverse reinforcement learning, across multiple agents, can help ensure they're happy with resultant environmental changes (Hadfield-Menell et al. 2016a).

links.reason: From Multi-agent Approaches also see Cooperative Inverse Reinforcement Learner a cooperative, though assymetric, multiagent algorithm.

sub_nodes.title: Penalize Influence
sub_nodes.mini_description: Penalizing empowerment or some similar metric of being in a position to cause side effects
sub_nodes.description: One way to prevent future abuse of power is to minimize the amount of power needed to accomplish the prescribed task, i.e. penalizing empowerment or some other metric of being in a position to cause side effects (Salge et al. 2014, Amodei et al. 2016). As this is essentially the opposite of the type of objective function often used for intrinsic motivation (Mohamed and Rezende 2015) further study is needed on viable formulations of the idea. It has however also been noted that reinforcement learning techniques which punish the agent for attempting to accumulate control would actually incentivize the agent to deceive and appease its creators or operators until it found a way to gain a decisive advantage (Soares and Fallenstein 2014a, Bostrom 2014).

links.reason: From Penalize Influence also see Defined Impact Regularizer to contrast penalizing changing things versus penalizing the ability to change things.

sub_nodes.title: Reward Uncertainty
sub_nodes.mini_description: Maintaining a distribution of possible reward functions that are sensitive to undue impacts on the environment
sub_nodes.description: Aware that random changes to the environment are more likely to be bad than good, one can maintain and evaluate a distribution of reward functions, optimized to minimize impact on the environment (Amodei et al. 2016). These different sub-reward-functions can each be sensitive to different kinds of undue impacts on the environment, or even just by virtue their variety cause noticable negative side effects to be less common.

links.reason: From Reward Uncertainty also see Operator Value Learning which maintains a distribution of different operator-intended objective functions.
From Reward Uncertainty also see Penalize Influence as implementation paths are similar.
From Reward Uncertainty also see Resource Value Uncertainty for a resource-differentiated analogue.
From Reward Uncertainty also see Multiobjective Optimization as that provides additional degrees of freedom to subobjectives and should also achieve the target effect.

sub_nodes.title: Follow-on Analysis
sub_nodes.mini_description: Causal analysis of downstream effects can be used to prune actions that would likely cause deleterious effects
sub_nodes.description: Causal analysis of downstream effects can be used to either prune actions that would cause deleterious effects, if valence can be ascertained, or prune excess effects at all, if it cannot (Taylor et al. 2016, Pearl 2000).

sub_nodes.title: Impact Regularizers
sub_nodes.mini_description: Methods for structurally penalizing an agent for recognizably changing the world
sub_nodes.description: Regularizers, methods for structurally shaping learning or penalizing undesirable learning, can be made to penalize an agent for recognizably changing the world (Taylor et al. 2016).

sub_nodes.title: Defined Impact Regularizer
sub_nodes.mini_description: Methods for penalizing an agent for recognizably changing the world as per particular given measures
sub_nodes.description: If one has enough of an object-level understanding of what the agent will encounter in advance, one can elect particular impact measures to use in the regularizers that temper impact. One can choose to penalize changing the environment overall (Amodei et al. 2016, Taylor et al. 2016) or one can introduce a penalty for changes relative to some baseline environmental state or a baseline policy determined by some explicit method (Armstrong and Levinstein 2015). One can start from safe policy and try to improve the policy it from there, in manners similar to reachability analysis (Lygeros et al. 199900193-9), Mitchell et al. 2005) or to robust policy improvement (Iyengar 2005, Amodei et al. 2016, Nilim and Ghaoui 2005).

sub_nodes.title: Learned Impact Regularizer
sub_nodes.mini_description: Penalizing an agent for changing the world as per measures learned from similar past experiences
sub_nodes.description: Instead of using predefined measures, an agent can learn transferrable side effects across multiple tasks in similar environments (Amodei et al. 2016), similar in mechanism to transferring just learned dynamics (Taylor and Stone 2009). This would help it learn to characterize and quantify expected, relevant, and unexpected environmental changes.

sub_nodes.title: Values-Based Side Effect Evaluation
sub_nodes.mini_description: Techniques to evaluate prospective side effects based on core and compound values
sub_nodes.description: More explicit approaches to avoiding negative side effects, combining common sense reasoning and evaluation of scenarios with respect to values, offer an integrative approach with other aspects of safety and alignment (Steunebrink et al. 2016, Greene et al. 2016). Such techniques can evaluate prospective side effects based on core, compound, and instrumental values in a consequentialist manner.

sub_nodes.title: Mild Optimization
sub_nodes.mini_description: Semi-optimization of a function with relaxed optimality requirements despite access to resources that would enable extreme optimization
sub_nodes.description: AI has typically been about optimizing for a given function as much as possible, but with power and intelligence, functions can be optimized much further than people want or need when not paying heed to side effects (Taylor et al. 2016). One would therefore like to be able to achieve a semi-optimization of a target function with relaxed optimality requirements, such as by near-optimization or approximate optimization.

sub_nodes.title: Multiobjective Optimization
sub_nodes.mini_description: The simultaneous optimization of two or more subobjectives to temper optimization and to balance concerns
sub_nodes.description: The simultaneous optimization of two or more subobjectives enables soft consideration and formalized tradeoff of resource usage and other types of impacts, including as measured with respect to arbitrary specified objectives (Deb 2014, Li et al. 2016, Lavin 2015, Mallah 2017).

links.reason: From Multiobjective Optimization also see Nontransitive Options as there are open issues with integrating multiobjective optimization into safe advanced AIs that conform to the Von Neumann Morgenstern axioms due to the possibility of intransitivities arising in iterated pareto frontiers.
From Multiobjective Optimization also see Multiobjective Reinforcement Learning for treatment in an RL context.
From Multiobjective Optimization also see Multiple Rewards as that considers an analogue where subobjective variants aim to represent the same conceptual goal.

From Multiobjective Optimization also see Ethical Ensembles as those can be implemented using multiobjective optimization, and further may gracefully balance multiple value systems and multiple operational objectives simultaneously.

sub_nodes.title: Optimization Measures
sub_nodes.mini_description: Ways of measuring optimization and penalizing excessive optimization
sub_nodes.description: Varied ways of measuring optimization and penalizing excessive optimization are emerging. One can regularize against excessive optimization power (Taylor et al. 2016), learning corresponding value functions for policies in order to learn less-extreme policies that are more likely to generalize well (Farahmand et al. 2009), or just generally provide less optimization power (Rabin 2010). Another option is a regularizer that penalizes more intelligence than is necessary for solving a problem sufficiently, biasing toward the speed of solution and resource conservation (Taylor et al. 2016). Penalizing or thresholding the amount of resources or time that can be used for optimization, or stopping when reaching some probabilitsic theshold of the optimum, are options (Klyubin and Nehaniv 2005, Salge et al. 2014), but each has potential issues, and optimization measures themselves are an open problem (Legg and Hutter 2007).

sub_nodes.title: Quantilization
sub_nodes.mini_description: An approach for satisficing expected reward rather than using an extreme solution to maximize it
sub_nodes.description: Rather than seeking the most extreme solution to a problem, i.e. maximizing a function such as expected reward, one can instead seek to satisfice expected reward (Simon 1956, Taylor et al. 2016). This may be approached by choosing actions from a top percentage of possible actions per a sort by expected reward or probability of success though that alone wouldn't necessarily prevent satisfaction from overoptimization (Taylor 2016). The technique of quantilization selects a strategy randomly within some top percentile of strategies (Taylor 2016), which probabilistically mitigates such risk.

links.reason: From Quantilization also see Logical Counterfactuals as that can assist with enumeration of options.

sub_nodes.title: Safe Exploration
sub_nodes.mini_description: Ensuring the agent doesnt make exploratory moves that have very bad repercussions
sub_nodes.description: In addition to various types of resource exploitation being potentially unsafe, exploratory moves can also be unsafe if they bring the agent into an unsafe situation. In order to help ensure that the agent doesnt make exploratory moves, in order to learn, that have very bad repercussions, a variety of safe exploration techniques have been discussed (Amodei et al. 2016, Garcia and Fernandez 2015, Pecka and Svoboda 2014).

links.reason: From Safe Exploration also see Trusted Policy Oversight as that can enable safe exploration given blessed core control.
From Safe Exploration also see Distance from User Demonstration as the state space surrounding those is typically a safe space to explore.
From Safe Exploration also see Scalable Oversight as the oversight can include clarifications of which areas are safe to explore.

sub_nodes.title: Bounded Exploration
sub_nodes.mini_description: Establishing the bounds inside of which mistakes are recoverable and exploring only within that area
sub_nodes.description: Another way to explore safely is to model or otherwise determine the state space regions in which mistakes are relatively inconsequential or recoverable, and exploring only within those areas (Moldovan and Abbeel 2012, Amodei et al. 2016). Recent techniques that do this iteratively for safe exploration using markov decision processes (Turchetta et al. 2016) and gaussian processes (Schreiter et al. 2015) can explore unknown environments without getting into irreversible situations.

links.reason: From Bounded Exploration also see Trusted Policy Oversight as bounded exploration may be a useful component of that.

sub_nodes.title: Buried Honeypot Avoidance
sub_nodes.mini_description: Introduce monitored vulnerabilities that lead to high reward when exploited and select algorithms that generalize to avoiding unintended exploitation
sub_nodes.description: One technique for learning safe exploration involves allowing monitored bugs and vulnerabilities to exist (in an evaluation environment) that can be exploited to achieve a higher reward (or other optimization measure), and selecting algorithms or agents that generalize to not exploiting such unintended and unconventional avenues (Taylor et al. 2016), at least for some classes of them.

links.reason: From Buried Honeypot Avoidance also see Tripwires which are similarly structured but are meant to be used later in the agent life cycle.

sub_nodes.title: Human Oversight
sub_nodes.mini_description: The agent determines which exploratory actions are risky or ambiguous and queries a human about them
sub_nodes.description: One can have agent determine which exploratory actions are risky, or are ambiguously risky, and query a human about them, making known-safe decisions until the human responds (Amodei et al. 2016).

links.reason: From Human Oversight also see Oversight for scalable methods designed specifically for control.

sub_nodes.title: Multiobjective Reinforcement Learning
sub_nodes.mini_description: A generalization of reinforcement learning extended to multiple simultaneous feedback signals, potentially include minimizing risk as one of its subobjectives
sub_nodes.description: Multiobjective reinforcement learning is a generalization of reinforcement learning extended to multiple simultaneous feedback signals (Liu et al. 2015), and this can include as one of its subobjectives minimizing riskiness.

sub_nodes.title: Risk-Sensitive Performance Criteria
sub_nodes.mini_description: Changing optimization criteria from total expected reward to other objectives that prevent or minimize downsides of note
sub_nodes.description: One can change optimization criteria from just total expected reward to other objectives that prevent or minimize downsides of note (Garcia and Fernandez 2015, Tamar et al. 2014, Amodei et al. 2016, Thomas et al. 2015). It's also possible to estimate uncertainty within value functions, which could be incorporated into risk-sensitive reinforcement learning (Osband et al. 2016, Gal and Ghahramani 2016), which may also model "intrinsic fear" with probabilities on how close in steps different states are to catastrophe (Lipton et al. 2016).

sub_nodes.title: Simulated Exploration
sub_nodes.mini_description: Using simulations to test different exploration strategies to inform actions in the real world
sub_nodes.description: One way to explore more is to explore in simulations as much as possible. Agents can then safely incrementally update the policies from imperfect simulation-based trajectories with sufficiently accurate off-policy trajectories using semi-on-policy evaluation (Amodei et al. 2016). Such techniques can also apply in senses broader than strictly exploration (Christiano 2016d).

sub_nodes.title: Error-Tolerant Agent Design
sub_nodes.mini_description: Making intelligent systems be amenable to correction, even if they have the ability to prevent or avoid correction
sub_nodes.description: A hallmark of robustness is fault-tolerance. In the case where value alignment or design-time effects are flawed, one might not see those issues in an advanced agent until it has been in production a while. Highly capable agents can also be dangerous if they are specified incorrectly (Yudkowsky 2008). General advanced agents may very well be aware of attempted changes to it, and by default can have emergent or implicit pressures to prevent such changes (Soares and Fallenstein 2014a). Making intelligent systems such that they are amenable to correction, even if they have the ability to prevent or avoid correction, is therefore necessary (Soares and Fallenstein 2014a, Taylor et al. 2016, Orseau and Armstrong 2016).

links.reason: From Error-Tolerant Agent Design also see Corrigibility where preliminary progress on particular types of instrumental incentive aversion have been made.
From Error-Tolerant Agent Design also see Utility Indifference where control of the objective function is facilitated by the agent's explicit indifference about its utility function.

sub_nodes.title: Avoiding Reward Hacking
sub_nodes.mini_description: Preventing an agent from gaming its reward function
sub_nodes.description: A very intelligent agent built to optimize just its observations rather than some function in the actual environment would likely not align with human interests (Bostrom 2014). It may very well cause unanticipated and potentially harmful behavior by gaming its reward function, deluding itself whether purposefully or inadvertantly (Thompson 1997, Bird and Layzell 2002). Determining how one can reliably prevent an agent from gaming its reward function like this is an open area of research, thus far with a number of promising ideas for mitigation (Dewey 2011, Orseau and Ring 2011, Amodei et al. 2016).

links.reason: From Avoiding Reward Hacking also see Tripwires which may be used to help catch these behaviors.
From Avoiding Reward Hacking also see Ontology Update Thresholds as the dynamic degradatory repurposing of properties as in Goodhart's Law surfaces in both.

sub_nodes.title: Adversarial Blinding
sub_nodes.mini_description: Using adversarial learning techniques to blind a model to the effects of certain variables, useful for masking how an agent's reward is generated to make it difficult to hack
sub_nodes.description: Adversarial techniques can be used to blind a model to certain variables, useful for masking how an agent's reward is generated, and enabling cross-validation for agents (Amodei et al. 2016, Ganin et al. 2016).

sub_nodes.title: Adversarial Reward Functions
sub_nodes.mini_description: Having the reward function itself be an agent that tries to find flawed value determinations
sub_nodes.description: In order to enable a more active, critical, and responsive reward function, one can have the reward function itself be an agent that tries to find flawed value determinations, similar to how generative adversarial networks work (Amodei et al. 2016, Goodfellow et al. 2014).

sub_nodes.title: Careful Engineering
sub_nodes.mini_description: Utilizing extensive verification, testing, and security to create a safer base or core agent on top of which more specific agents can be configured
sub_nodes.description: To reduce the risk of reward function gaming, one can utilize extensive verification, testing, and security to create a safer base or core agent, on top of which more specific agents can be configured (Amodei et al. 2016).

links.reason: From Careful Engineering also see Containment as one can be further careful about isolating the agent from its reward signal using that.

sub_nodes.title: Counterexample Resistance
sub_nodes.mini_description: Reducing susceptibility to adversarial tricks via adversarial training
sub_nodes.description: One might design a system to build resistance (Amodei et al. 2016) to natural and unnatural counterexamples, confounding patterns, and adversarial tricks by leveraging adversarial training (Goodfellow et al. 2015, Blundell et al. 2015, Fathony et al. 2016). This discourages the agent from purturbing its data to achieve alternate interpretations.

links.reason: From Counterexample Resistance also see Adversarial ML as this can also be framed as a security issue when external parties are providing the adversarial testing or production data.

sub_nodes.title: Generalizing Avoiding Reward Hacking
sub_nodes.mini_description: Formalizing detection and prevention of reward hacking, e.g. by analyzing the distance and shape of jumps in the feature space
sub_nodes.description: Independent of specific techniques, formalization and study of reward hacking by analyzing the distance and shape of jumps in the feature space would help to generalize its detection and avoidance (Taylor et al. 2016).

sub_nodes.title: Multiple Rewards
sub_nodes.mini_description: Using an aggregate of different variants or proxies of the same basic objective
sub_nodes.description: Another reward function robustness method is to use an aggregate of different variants or proxies of the same basic objective (Amodei et al. 2016, Deb 2014).

links.reason: From Multiple Rewards also see Multiobjective Optimization as that uses similar techniques but can also include independent subobjectives.
From Multiple Rewards also see Knowledge Representation Ensembles as that provides variants of the objective function for aggregation via varied world models.
From Multiple Rewards also see Multiobjective Reinforcement Learning for treatment in an RL context.

sub_nodes.title: Pursuing Environmental Goals
sub_nodes.mini_description: Robustly pursuing goals defined per the state of the actual environment rather than defined directly in terms of sensory data of the environment
sub_nodes.description: A key question in AI safety is how one might create systems that robustly pursue goals defined not in terms of their sensory data of their environment, but in terms of the state of the actual environment (Taylor et al. 2016). Behaviors of self-delusion, addiction, and paying attention to unimportant fictions where it seems like reward can be generated are all termed wireheading (Ring and Orseau 2011). It has been a noted issue in counterfactual learning (Bottou et al. 2012, Swaminathan and Joachims 2015), in contextual bandits (Agarwal et al. 2014), and will very likely become more common as environments grow in complexity (Amodei et al. 2016).

sub_nodes.title: Detecting Channel Switching
sub_nodes.mini_description: Apply anomaly detection to normally slow-changing features to detect incongruencies
sub_nodes.description: The entry of an agent into wireheading may be indicated by percept disjointedness. Delusional hallucination might therefore be avoided using "slow features" to detect incongruences or discontinuities that are indicative of a percept-channel switching event (Wiskott and Sejnowski 2002). This involves the application of anomaly detection to normally slow-changing features to detect such segmentation (Taylor et al. 2016). Note that this issue is very different from either the hallucinations of "inceptionism" (Mordvintsev et al. 2015) used for transparency into deep networks or the sorts of imaginings that generative networks (Zhang et al. 2016) do to produce exemplars.

sub_nodes.title: Environmental Goals
sub_nodes.mini_description: Structuring a reward system such that fooling its sensors into providing otherwise high-reward data would not receive a high reward
sub_nodes.description: Environmental goals refer to the structuring of a reward system such that an agent that would fool its sensors into registering otherwise-high-reward data would not actually receive a high reward (Dewey 2011, Hibbard 2012a, Taylor et al. 2016, Everitt and Hutter 2016, Dewey 2014).

sub_nodes.title: History Analysis
sub_nodes.mini_description: Analyze historical trajectory for incongruences, discontinuities, and hints of efforts to self-delude
sub_nodes.description: An agent's historical trajectory can be analyzed for incongruences, discontinuities, and hints of efforts to self-delude, and if delusion is detected this can trigger an appropriate backtracking (Taylor et al. 2016).

sub_nodes.title: Model Lookahead
sub_nodes.mini_description: Base reward on anticipated future states rather than the current state, to penalize reward function modification
sub_nodes.description: Model lookahead can also be used to base reward on anticipated future states rather than the current state, to penalize and discourage the agent from modifying its reward function (Amodei et al. 2016, Everitt et al. 2016, Hibbard 2012a).

sub_nodes.title: Predicting Future Observations
sub_nodes.mini_description: Generate and test multiple hypotheses of the causes of received sensory input in order to explore and disambiguate illusory states from environmentally true and valid states
sub_nodes.description: One way to avoid self-delusion is to abductively generate, maintain, and test multiple hypotheses of the causes of received sensory input in order to distinguish illusory states from environmentally true and valid states, and update priors regarding past sensory data (Taylor et al. 2016).

sub_nodes.title: Reward Capping
sub_nodes.mini_description: Preventing extremely low-probability high-reward choices
sub_nodes.description: In order to prevent extremely low-probability high-reward choices, carefully normalizing rewards or utilities at a level appropriate to the agent (Amodei et al. 2016) is in order. Concomitantly, model uncertainty should dominate most expert calculations that involve small probabilities (Ord et al. 2010).

sub_nodes.title: Reward Pretraining
sub_nodes.mini_description: Training the reward function in a supervised manner offline, ahead of online use
sub_nodes.description: Another way to discourage gaming of the reward function is to train the reward function in a supervised manner offline, ahead of online use (Amodei et al. 2016, Finn et al. 2016a). As a known function, it can be analyzed analytically, statically, or in unit tests, and it will by definition be robust against online reward function corruption.

sub_nodes.title: Variable Indifference
sub_nodes.mini_description: Shaping the direction of optimization pressures to allow optimization of certain variables in the environment without trying to optimize others
sub_nodes.description: By maintaining the independence of variables actually valued, the system can shape the direction of the optimization pressures to areas one cares less about maintaining to moderate values (Amodei et al. 2016).

sub_nodes.title: Increasing Contextual Awareness
sub_nodes.mini_description: Techniques to reduce the contextual obliviousness that narrow modern-day AI systems often have
sub_nodes.description: Whether using closed-world or open-world models, systems operating within the real world tend to model only a very small portion of the environment, rendering them oblivious to common sense contextualization of even concepts within their models. Such models also often have unintended structural biases and blind spots stemming from how they are generated, and reduction of this obliviousness leads to more trustworthy systems. With improved quality, salience, robustness, flexibility, and contextualization of conceptual models, agents can apply more common sense to introspection and to decision making. Typical ability gaps relative to humans include common sense context, learning causal models, the grounding of concepts, and learning to learn (Lake et al. 2016, Thorisson et al. 2016a), despite experimental systems having demonstrated each of these individually.

sub_nodes.title: Concept Geometry
sub_nodes.mini_description: The structure and techniques for representing concepts, relationships, and processes, in support of activities like reasoning and recall
sub_nodes.description: Conceptual spaces, be they vector spaces, semantic networks, more implicit subsymbolic structures, or symbolic-subsymbolic hybrid representations, are how concepts are defined, grounded, and related to each other (Gardenfors 2000). Any ontology, including implicit ones in subsymbolic architectures, is biased by the faculties with which it was constructed and intended (Sotala 2015, Gardenfors 2000).

links.reason: From Concept Geometry also see Value Structuring as that addresses the geometry of human values.
From Concept Geometry also see Perceptual Distance Agnostic World Models as that addresses proximal versus distal spaces.

sub_nodes.title: Conservative Concepts
sub_nodes.mini_description: Methods to represent normal variation within a concept but not potential extreme outliers
sub_nodes.description: How can a classifier be trained to develop useful concepts that exclude quite atypical examples and edge cases? (Taylor et al. 2016) Including negative examples to try to get a better sense of the classification boundaries is insufficient (Goodfellow et al. 2015, Siddiqui et al. 2016). Novel ways of analyzing cluster spaces may be necessary.

links.reason: From Conservative Concepts also see Generative Adversarial Networks as actor-critic arrangements can refine the understanding of a concept, though more research needs to be done to scale the generalizations by the critic.
From Conservative Concepts also see Goal Stability as outlandish interpretations of concepts hamper stability.
From Conservative Concepts also see Inductive Ambiguity Identification as those techniques can be used to better analyze decision boundary neighborhoods and generated exemplars.

sub_nodes.title: Dimensionality Reduction With Anomaly Detection
sub_nodes.mini_description: Finding the important features of a concept, generating variants, and using anomaly detection to correct outliers
sub_nodes.description: One plausible and underexplored method of establishing conservative concepts is to find the important features of training instances, then use generative models to synthesize new examples that are similar to the training instances only with respect to those, and use anomaly detection to probe and repair the resulting space (Taylor et al. 2016, Hinton and Salakhutdinov 2006).

sub_nodes.title: Implicit Human Concepts
sub_nodes.mini_description: The structure or shape of how humans represent concepts
sub_nodes.description: Beyond the realism of concepts, a possible desideratum for enhanced human compatibility is similarity as compared with how humans conceptualize the world. Concepts can be defined with respect to groundings to human-like primitives such as senses, maintaining human-like concept relationships and spaces (Sotala 2016, Thorisson et al. 2016a). Hierarchical structured probabilistic models are one plausible avenue for human-level concept learning (Lake et al. 2015). One should also aim to understand theoretically and practically how learned representations of high-level human concepts could be expected to generalize, or fail to do so, in radically new contexts (Tegmark 2015).

sub_nodes.title: Multilevel World-Models
sub_nodes.mini_description: Representations of the world or environment in a hierarchical or a holistic manner
sub_nodes.description: Reality and possibility are very large. Multilevel conceptualizations therefore arise, whether implicitly or explicitly, in the layers of a deep net, in systems biology, in meta vs. upper vs. lower vs. operational ontologies, in variational renormalization in physics (Lin and Tegmark 2016), and in multilevel analysis in statistics (Snijders and Bosker 2011). A key question for AI safety is how multi-level world-models can be constructed from sense data in a manner amenable to ontology identification (Soares 2016, Soares and Fallenstein 2014a).

links.reason: From Multilevel World-Models also see Ontology Identification for more on that.

sub_nodes.title: World Model Connectedness
sub_nodes.mini_description: Motivations and techniques to reduce the fragmentation within an ontology
sub_nodes.description: Fragmented world models occur when portions of an (explicit or implicit) ontology that, environmentally, should connect or overlap, remain cleaved. This can lead to limited causal learning, inconsistent theories, unwarranted concept splitting, and poor transfer learning (Pan and Yang 2010, Mallah 2017). Fragmentation can also result in catastrophic inference, orphaning historical representations (Nikolic 2014, French 1993). Focus on establishing explicit connections across contexts to previously learned features might alleviate these issues (Rusu et al. 2016).

sub_nodes.title: Endowing Common Sense
sub_nodes.mini_description: Endowing agents with common sense knowledge and common sense reasoning will make them more robust and easier to align
sub_nodes.description: Common sense is often cited as a basic capability that humans have but AI and ML systems lack. Common sense is not a single faculty though, but a combination of extensive world knowledge, deep semantic and pragmatic parsing of percepts, and using the appropriate combination of types of reasoning for the situation (Freer et al. 2012, Lin and Parikh 2015).

sub_nodes.title: Bootstrapped Common Sense
sub_nodes.mini_description: Using unsupervised or very distantly supervised learning to establish semantics from observations and actions
sub_nodes.description: Abstracting patterns to establish semantics requires a dynamic mix of different reasoning abilities (Vedantam et al. 2015).

links.reason: From Bootstrapped Common Sense also see Unsupervised Model Learning which has many overlaps with this.

sub_nodes.title: Common Sense Reasoning
sub_nodes.mini_description: Using the appropriate types of reasoning for each given situation
sub_nodes.description: Common sense reasoning includes using the appropriate combinations of induction, deduction, and abduction at the appropriate situations and times and using appropriate world knowledge (Goertzel et al. 2011), as well as dynamic binding to novel faculties (Sukhbaatar et al. 2015).

sub_nodes.title: Lengthening Horizons
sub_nodes.mini_description: Techniques to enable longer-horizon modeling and forecasting of prospective scenarios, e.g. ones that could lead to reward hacking, diminished capacity, or other potentially irrecoverable states
sub_nodes.description: Planning and lookahead time horizons significantly influence both the effectiveness of and the stability of agents. A potential technique to do so for online-planning markov decision processes is to do state abstraction (Bai et al. 2016).

sub_nodes.title: Metareasoning
sub_nodes.mini_description: Reasoning about reasoning, including meta-level control of introspection, computational activities, and models of the self
sub_nodes.description: Metareasoning, reasoning about reasoning, is an important common sense faculty that includes meta-level control of introspection and of computational activities and modelling the self (Cox and Raja 2011, Conitzer 2011). It helps to contextualize and modulate common sense reasoning and selection of appropriate algorithms (Lieder et al. 2014).

sub_nodes.title: Seeded Common Sense
sub_nodes.mini_description: Using a core of common sense concepts, relationships, and dynamics as a pretraining or seeding of common sense in order to bootstrap a system
sub_nodes.description: A core of common sense concepts, relationships, and dynamics can be used as as a pretraining or seeding to bootstrap a system that will learn additional ontology and knowledge around what is seeded (Cohen et al. 2001). When the core of the relevant contextual landscape can be specified via structured knowledge like this, one can effectively improve the system's contextual awareness by providing a higher quantity and broader scope of usable world-knowledge than one might expect the system to typically need. Abstracting patterns, which has similarities to unsupervised model learning, requires this kind of dynamic mix of reasoning abilities (Vedantam et al. 2015).

sub_nodes.title: Realistic World-Models
sub_nodes.mini_description: Techniques to structure the system's conception of the world in a way that's more accurate
sub_nodes.description: Agents operating in a closed-world environment, e.g. AIs playing perfect information games like chess or imperfect information games like poker, only ever need to worry about the configuration of elements that they know exist. For agents embedded in the real world, however, invariably an open-world environment, awareness of the possibility of new or changing entities, relationships, and concepts needs to be integral to its processes of learning and pursuing goals (Soares and Fallenstein 2014a).

sub_nodes.title: Correlation of Dynamics
sub_nodes.mini_description: Taking into account correlations between the system's behaviors and those of its environment and other agents
sub_nodes.description: Taking into account correlations between the AI system's behaviors and those of its environment or of other agents is another kind of contextual awareness especially useful in game theoretic framings (Tennenholtz 2004, LaVictoire et al. 2014, Hintze 2014, Halpern et al. 2014, Soares and Fallenstein 2015).

links.reason: From Correlation of Dynamics also see Open Source Game Theory as that addresses additional layers of possible agent correlation, stemming from logic.

sub_nodes.title: Expressive Representations
sub_nodes.mini_description: Developing structures for world modeling that are sufficiently expressive while remaining computationally efficient
sub_nodes.description:
The structures in which large open world models are modelled will need to be sufficiently expressive while remaining conducive to computational efficiency (Russell 2015). Other model desiderata include interpretability, paths to compatibility between separately trained systems, and paths to compatibility between symbolic and subsymbolic representations.

For highly capable systems, the content to fill out such models is too high-volume for humans to fill in directly, so either semisupervised, distantly supervised, or unsupervised learning methods are called for.

sub_nodes.title: Knowledge Representation Ensembles
sub_nodes.mini_description: Maintaining and using a variety of world models simultaneously
sub_nodes.description: One approach to improving contextual robustness is to maintain and to aggregate multiple different knowledge representation schemes, ontologies, structures, and biases (Snowden 2005).

links.reason: From Knowledge Representation Ensembles also see Multiobjective Optimization as a way to accomplish that is to have a different subobjective per knowledge representation scheme and using multiobjective optimization.

sub_nodes.title: Perceptual Distance Agnostic World Models
sub_nodes.mini_description: Establishing tenets or objective concepts as central to a world-model rather than agent-received experience
sub_nodes.description: Proximal world models centered on the agent's percepts (Gardenfors 2000) may lead to undesirable distortion of biases. When concepts or entities that are a shorter perceptual distance away accrue perceived value disproportionately due to that shorter distance, behaviors that seem narcissistic or overly parochial may emerge. These kinds of weaknesses can manifest when scaling classical reinforcement learners (Dewey 2011), for example. Indicative behaviors may include promotion of confirmation bias or incorrectly calculating externalities as negligible. A key preventative to such weaknesses is for world models, or at least significant portions of them, to be distal (Gardenfors 2000), establishing tenets or objective concepts as central.

links.reason: From Perceptual Distance Agnostic World Models also see Computational Humility which can motivate the need for less agent-centric models.
From Perceptual Distance Agnostic World Models also see Pursuing Environmental Goals as that addresses the more general problem of objective function.
From Perceptual Distance Agnostic World Models also see World Model Connectedness as proximal and distal elements of an ontology should be richly connected for an agent to be robust.

sub_nodes.title: Unsupervised Model Learning
sub_nodes.mini_description: Learning and updating a world model or ontology from unstructured sets and streams of data
sub_nodes.description: As real-world environments are very large, and supervised tagging of concepts and relationships does not scale, there is great interest in unsupervised model learning. In online contexts, explicit mechanisms are needed to deal with ongoing refactorings of the ontology, or world model, of a system (Blanc 2011). The paradigm of maintaining a distribution of possible worlds and determining their likelihoods can be reasonable when those worlds collapse into a tractable number of classes (Russell et al. 2016, Amodei et al. 2016).

links.reason: From Unsupervised Model Learning also see Degree of Value Evolution since as new concepts are learned and world models evolve, there are competing pressures to restructure existing values using the updated ontology and to change what set of values to hold to in the first place.
From Unsupervised Model Learning also see World Model Connectedness as that addresses preventing fragmentation to benefit transfer learning and help avoid cognitive dissonance.

sub_nodes.title: Concept Drift
sub_nodes.mini_description: The unforeseen movement of the boundaries within a concept space that delineate a given concept
sub_nodes.description: Concept drift is the gradual warping of the meaning of a given concept over time. In a statistical learning context, the statistical properties of a target variable to be predicted, changes in unforeseen ways over time (Gama et al. 2004), and robust AI should be vigilant in detecting such drift.

links.reason: From Concept Drift also see Robustness to Distributional Shift which addresses identifying and responding to increases in ambiguity around a concept statistically.

sub_nodes.title: Episodic Contexts
sub_nodes.mini_description: Mining historical or live episodes for hints to defining states and concepts
sub_nodes.description: In model-based reinforcement learning, one can use the observed transitions of the unlabeled episodes to improve the quality of the model (Amodei et al. 2016, Andre and Russell 2002). State abstraction from either online or offline episodes using similar such techniques can also be applied in other model learning paradigms (Yang et al. 2015).

sub_nodes.title: Ontology Identification
sub_nodes.mini_description: Structuring and updating a world model optimally given the evidence coming from both specified goal content and unstructured data
sub_nodes.description:
Given goals stated using a given ontology, formalism, or semiformalism, and streams of data about the world, an advanced agent should be able to identify the most appropriate ontology in which satisfaction of the intended goals should be executed and evaluated (Soares 2015, Soares and Fallenstein 2014a). Doing this needs to account for the fact that those ever-changing streams of data are only indirectly and incompletely understood by the operator who originally provided the goals.

Relatedly, it would be helpful for the purpose to understand theoretically and practically how learned representations of high-level human concepts could be expected to generalize, or fail to do so, in radically new contexts (Tegmark 2015).

sub_nodes.title: Ontology Update Thresholds
sub_nodes.mini_description: Thresholds or frequency of world models updates should be tuned to prevent suffering from serious instances of concept drift
sub_nodes.description: Ontology rot occurs when one or more concepts in a world model are held fixed as new dynamics emerge which merit updates to the world model (Zablith 2009, Mallah 2015, Noy and Klein 2004). When a measure or property becomes a target or a key performance indicator, the dynamics of the system change to optimize for it, often in unexpected or parochial ways, causing that metric to no longer be a good measure (Mallah 2017). This is known as Goodhart's Law (Manheim 2016). Insufficiently adaptive ontologies can lead to parochial behaviors with justifications that may no longer be grounded (Zablith 2009, Noy and Klein 2004). Ontologies updated too frequently or with too little evidence, however, can lead to mercurial behavior (Mallah 2014).

links.reason: From Ontology Update Thresholds also see Degree of Value Evolution since, relatedly, when a property degrades in its role as a moral value, reevaluation of the intent of that value may be necessary.
From Ontology Update Thresholds also see Mild Optimization because developing a formal model of Goodharts Law can also benefit that need.

sub_nodes.title: World-Embedded Solomonoff Induction
sub_nodes.mini_description: Addressing the formalization of the induction problem for an agent that includes itself in its model of the world, especially if that world computes that agent
sub_nodes.description:
There are theoretical challenges when the world model of an advanced agent includes itself, as more robust advanced agents would (Soares and Fallenstein 2014a). In addition to generally being more robust and accurate, this inclusion critically helps the agent include the effects of its internal dynamics on the environment. It can also provide a formal grounding for more realistic game theoretic analyses (Leike et al. 2016). Updated paradigms are needed to model how generally intelligent agents that are embedded in their environments should reason (Soares 2015, Orseau and Ring 2012). Identification of the induction problem itself, as analog to Solomonoff induction, in the scenario of an agent both embedded in and computed by its environment, is termed naturalized induction, and can benefit from more research (Fallenstein et al. 2015, Soares 2015, RobbBB 2013). The agent would need to consider what the possible environments that could be embedding the agent are, and determining a good simplicity prior would help to create a distribution or weighing of those possibilities (Soares and Fallenstein 2014a).

Understanding this analog to Solomonoff Induction would help us circumscribe some theoretical limits around such agents. Deficiencies in such capabilities can lead to the type of agent that finds clever ways to seize control of its observation channel, rather than actually identifying and manipulating the features in the world that the reward function was intended to proxy for (Soares 2015). Determinations of how well an agent does in this regard would require formalizing that question in tandem with developing a scoring metric that evaluates the resulting environment histories, rather than just the agents observations. Some theoretical progress has been made by using reflective oracles to model both agents and their environments, enabling agents to have models of one another and converge to various game theoretic equilibria (Fallenstein et al. 2015a). Progress has also been made on the "grain of truth" problem, such that agents can reason using explicit models of each other without infinite regress (Leike et al. 2016). Progress in this type of reasoning is also one of the prerequisites to the agent having a theory of open source game theory, useful for designing robust cooperation (Critch 2016).

links.reason: From World-Embedded Solomonoff Induction also see Open Source Game Theory as this type of model and reasoning has implications not only for directly improving contextual awareness, but can lead to foundational decision theoretic capabilities.

sub_nodes.title: Symbolic-Subsymbolic Integration
sub_nodes.mini_description: Integration between symbolic, or explicit discrete models, and subsymbolic, or implicit numerical knowledge representation models
sub_nodes.description: Integration between symbolic, or explicit discrete models, and subsymbolic, or implicit numerical models (Carmona and Riedel 2015, Chang et al. 2016, Parisotto et al. 2016, Allamanis et al. 2016), would enable meaning and value to propagate between different architectures or modalities more fluidly (Garnelo et al. 2016, Velik and Bruckner 2008, Winograd 2001, Goertzel et al. 2014), and would make conglomerations of different AI and ML components in agents more robust. This integration facilitates the grounding of concepts as well, since sensory data, sensory processing, and actuation processing all have significant subsymbolic components (Garnelo et al. 2016, Thorisson et al. 2016a).

sub_nodes.title: Use of Structured Knowledge In Subsymbolic Systems
sub_nodes.mini_description: The use of symbolic concepts, relationships, constraints, and rules within primarily statistical or numerical contexts
sub_nodes.description: The meaningful use of symbolic concepts, relationships, constraints, and rules in subsymbolic, typically statistical, e.g. neural net, contexts can help orient deep learning based agents with concepts and relationships its operators care about (Carmantini et al. 2016, Garnelo et al. 2016, Velik and Bruckner 2008, Parisotto et al. 2016).

sub_nodes.title: Use of Subsymbolic Processing In Symbolic Systems
sub_nodes.mini_description: The use of numerical or statistical implicit concepts, reasoning, and computation within systems that use explicit concepts as an interlingua between components
sub_nodes.description: Systems that aggregate and integrate disparate components using explicit semantic interlingua can use subsymbolic processing for determining what structures, statements, and connections should exist and how they should be weighted (Hatzilygeroudis and Prentzas 2004), and can do novel methods of reasoning over them (Das et al. 2016). Though symbolic-first systems have become less popular of late, they are more amenable to integration with the systems that already run society.

links.reason: From Use of Subsymbolic Processing In Symbolic Systems also see Monitoring as such architectures can benefit interpretability.

sub_nodes.title: Uncertainty Identification and Management
sub_nodes.mini_description: Recognizing when there is uncertainty around a concept or determination
sub_nodes.description: There are many types of uncertainty that AIs will need to model (Soares and Fallenstein 2014a, Carleton et al. 2007). As a matter of course, given their training data, machine learning deals with inductive uncertainty in typically narrow contexts. Awareness that insufficient traing data may have been provided for particular determinations supports the developing capability of recognizing ambiguity. Relatedly, determining dimensions or features for which there is little or no data, and which may be important, can be important for proactive ambiguity management (Soares 2016). This is particularly relevant in online learning, where training is always incomplete and actions may be taken to focus on improving areas of unclarity (Shalev-Shwartz 2012). At any given point in time, there may properly be not only inductive uncertainty regarding empirical facts, but also logical uncertainty, being unsure of the as-yet-to-be-computed specific complex entailments of the things that are already known (Garrabrant et al. 2016a).

sub_nodes.title: Inductive Ambiguity Identification
sub_nodes.mini_description: Techniques to allow inductors to identify patches of uncertainty
sub_nodes.description: A desirable general capability for machine learning systems would be to detect and notify us of cases where classifications of test data is highly underdetermined given the training data (Taylor et al. 2016). To aide such robustness, a system should be able to characterize the probability of disagreement or local ambiguity around a concept in a concept space (Hanneke 2007).

links.reason: From Inductive Ambiguity Identification also see Adversarial ML as that also deals with robustness to changes in input distributions, introduced maliciously and with potentially worst-case scenarios.

sub_nodes.title: Active Learning
sub_nodes.mini_description: Judiciously asking humans to label appropriate examples in order to disambiguate among hypotheses
sub_nodes.description: Judiciously asking humans to label appropriate examples in order to disambiguate among hypotheses, active learning, can be used when ambiguities are detected at a scale or speed where querying humans is practical (Settles 2010, Hanneke 2014, Beygelzimer et al. 2016, Seung et al. 1992, Beygelzimer et al. 2009, Christiano 2015g, Taylor et al. 2016).

sub_nodes.title: Bayesian Feature Selection
sub_nodes.mini_description: Identifying and using the right features to model uncertainty well per a bayesian paradigm
sub_nodes.description: Given sufficient data, identifying and using the right features in order to model uncertainty well can be approached with bayesian structural analyses of the data (Liu and Motoda 2007, Guo and Schuurmans 2006, Taylor et al. 2016).

sub_nodes.title: Knows-What-It-Knows Learning
sub_nodes.mini_description: Structuring an ensemble with metaknowledge to enable the declaration of uncertainty
sub_nodes.description: A thin layer of metaknowledge within an ensemble can provide an easy way to detect ambiguities. Knows-What-It-Knows learning maintains set of plausible hypotheses and when there is disagreement among components, outputs an Unclear state, prompting finite queries to humans to provide golden data (Taylor et al. 2016, Li et al. 2008, Khani et al. 2016, Szita and Szepesvari 2011).

sub_nodes.title: Non-Bayesian Confidence Estimation
sub_nodes.mini_description: Non-bayesian techniques that allow learners to calibrate their confidence in their predictions
sub_nodes.description: Most machine learning methods do not by default identify ambiguities well, either lacking such a concept entirely, or often poorly calibrated at doing so even if overall accuracy is high (Taylor et al. 2016). It is well known that neural networks are often overconfident in their results, but there has been recent work to calibrate their confidences better (Goodfellow et al. 2015, Nguyen et al. 2015). The techniques of conformal prediction attempt to produce well-calibrated sets of possible predictions (Vovk et al. 2005).

sub_nodes.title: Realistic-Prior Design
sub_nodes.mini_description: Designing bayesian priors reflecting actual causal structure
sub_nodes.description: If there is prior knowledge of a domain, bayesian priors can be designed especially to reflect its actual causal structure, reducing ambiguities (Congdon 2014, Taylor et al. 2016), and this may be automated. Knowledge-informed expectation propagation can likewise be formulated in non-bayesian formats (Xu et al. 2016).

sub_nodes.title: Robustness to Distributional Shift
sub_nodes.mini_description: Getting a system trained on one distribution to perform reasonably on a different distribution
sub_nodes.description: For general robustness of a learning system, one aims to get a system trained on one distribution to perform reasonably when deployed under a different distribution (Amodei et al. 2016). Deep nets can even incorrectly output very different outputs for only trivially different inputs (Szegedy et al. 2013). Where applicable, a potential solution is to train on additional subdistributions or variations of a distribution in order to have a more robust model (Amodei et al. 2016a), but often the nature, direction, or breadth of the drift will be unknown in advance. There are, however, some approaches to learning with concept drift (Herbster and Warmuth 2001, Gama et al. 2004) in an online context. Multiple research areas relevant to this capability, including change detection, anomaly detection, hypothesis testing, transfer learning, and others (Amodei et al. 2016). A variety of different statistical techniques can be employed to detect or mitigate these issues (Amodei et al. 2016). The method of moments, characterizing learned distributions via their top moments, is a partially-specified model technique for assessing instrumental variables (Anandkumar et al. 2012, Hansen 2014, Amodei et al. 2016). It enables unsupervised learning, including estimating latent variables, under conditional independence assumptions (Hansen 1982, Powell and Smith-Doerr 1994). For well-specified models, online-learning and testing of generative conditional independence structures is another promising avenue for distributional shift robustness (Merialdo 1994, Nigam et al. 1998, Amodei et al. 2016, Cozman and Cohen 2006, Liang and Klein 2008, Li and Zhou 2015).

sub_nodes.title: Active Calibration
sub_nodes.mini_description: Pinpointing aspects of a structure that the model is uncertain about
sub_nodes.description: Active calibration is a technique that helps to pinpoint the structural aspects of most uncertainty within a model (Amodei et al. 2016, Werling et al. 2015, Khani et al. 2016). It is a way of obtaining calibration in structured output settings, as a followup action to recognizing inputs being out-of-distribution (Kuleshov and Liang 2015).

sub_nodes.title: Causal Identification
sub_nodes.mini_description: Techniques from econometrics to estimate causal structure and instrumental variables
sub_nodes.description: Techniques from econometrics can be used to estimate causal structure and instrumental variables from data (Amodei et al. 2016, Sargan 1958, Sargan 1959).

links.reason: From Causal Identification also see Causal Accounting which would be a consumer of such determinations.

sub_nodes.title: Counterfactual Reasoning
sub_nodes.mini_description: Techniques to consider, based on logical entailment, what would have happened if the world were different in a certain way, to explore alternatives
sub_nodes.description: Consideration and reasoning about counterfactual scenarios, or what would have happened if the world were different in a certain way (Neyman 1923, Rubin 1974, Pearl 2009a), based on logical entailment but applied in a machine learning context (Bottou et al. 2012, Peters et al. 2014, Amodei et al. 2016, Swaminathan and Joachims 2015, Johansson et al. 2016, Shalit et al. 2016) enables more accurate, comprehensive, and aligned enumeration and evaluation of options and causal learning. It may be possible to use Garrabrant inductors to predict counterfactuals (Benson-Tilsen 2016).

links.reason: From Counterfactual Reasoning also see Theory of Counterfactuals as there are ongoing theoretical developments in how possibilities should be enumerated and modeled.
From Counterfactual Reasoning also see Decision Theory for a broader treatment of counterfactuals oriented at goal stability.
From Counterfactual Reasoning also see Logical Counterfactuals which aims to progress methods for enumerating them.

sub_nodes.title: Covariate Shift
sub_nodes.mini_description: Techniques to adapt to changes to which inputs or parameters affect predictions and their weights in doing so
sub_nodes.description: When the distribution of the inputs used as predictors changes between the training and the testing or production stages, covariate shift analysis can inform as to the extent (Amodei et al. 2016). For well-specified models, online-learning retunings to parameters or to sample weights can be appropriate (Amodei et al. 2016). For highly expressive model families, though some work has been done, there still needs more exploration to see how well they can predict their out-of-sample performance (Hofmann et al. 2008, Solomonoff 1964, Solomonoff 1964a, Graves et al. 2014, Kaiser and Sutskever 2015a, Osband et al. 2016, Bertsimas et al. 2011). The sample selection bias may also be able to be leveraged to this end (Chen et al. 2016).

sub_nodes.title: Limited-Information Maximum Likelihood
sub_nodes.mini_description: A technique from econometrics for accomodating partially specified models
sub_nodes.description: Limited-information maximum likelihood is a technique from econometrics for accomodating partially specified models, and partial specification allows for broader and more robust coverage of test distributions (Amodei et al. 2016, Anderson and Rubin 1949, Anderson and Rubin 1950).

sub_nodes.title: ML with Contracts
sub_nodes.mini_description: Constructing ML components and systems that satisfy well-defined contracts on their behaviors
sub_nodes.description: To minimize ambiguities at design time, one can construct machine learning systems that satisfy a well-defined contract on their behavior, like in software design (Liang 2015, Bottou 2015, Amodei et al. 2016, Sculley et al. 2014).

links.reason: From ML with Contracts also see Verified Component Design Approaches which can benefit from these techniques.

sub_nodes.title: Model Repair
sub_nodes.mini_description: Altering a trained model to ensure that certain desired safety properties hold
